during 1962–2011. Dashed lines are trend lines. K represents the slope (i.e., rate of change (°C/year));
all the slopes of trends were significant (
< 0.05). Anomaly is the difference between the temperature
of one year (corresponding to the X-axis) and the average temperature of 50 years.
, and STR for each of the 360 stations were calculated
separately. It was evident that soil warming occurred across most of China, particularly in the
northeast (Figure 3). This is consistent with the previous results of changes in air temperature in
China [5,6], with only Shanghai Province, Guangdong Province, and southeast Tibet having a cooling
Based on a transect from north to south, the warming trend in
, this increase reduced both from north to south and from west to east. For some
stations, there was actually a cooling trend for
. Most of these stations were located in northern
China, where irrigation has been implemented to enhance agriculture. Presumably, the
evapotranspiration during summer contributed to the obvious decrease in
rose at a faster pace than
decreased. As a consequence, SDTR decreased for most stations, although a few stations had

erence between the temperature of one

Int. J. Environ. Res. Public Health
Spatial patterns of changes in soil surface temperatures (
1962–2011 (°C/year) at 360 observational stations in China. The color of the circles indicates the
magnitude of change. Solid circles with point indicate significance level of
> 0.05. Maps in this figure were created by ArcGIS 9.3 (ESRI, 2008).
The seasonal and annual trends were similar, with large changes in
regions and small changes in the southern regions in each season. Furthermore, the largest changes
occurred in winter. Some of these differences were attributed to the summer monsoon, which
accounts for the majority of the year’s precipitation and contributes to the south being much wetter
than the north (Figure 4). The stations experiencing the highest warming were located in western
China, most of Inner Mongolia, a portion of the northeast and Yunnan Province. In the rainy summer
decreased across large areas of central China (Figure 4), which substantially
decreased the SDTR. In the fall, the reduced trend in
Based on these regional disparities in SDTR across China, we inferred that the changes in

year) at 360 observational stations in China. The color of the circles indicates the

0.05. Maps in this ﬁgure were created by ArcGIS 9.3 (ESRI, 2008).
